Award.AwardTitle: Investigating Academic Climates and Institutional Contexts for Science Faculty with Education Specialties (SFES) across the U.S.

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This is an exploratory study of the role of Science Faculty with Education Specialties (SFES) in traditional STEM departments. These are faculty scientists who take on specialized roles in science education in their discipline. The enrichment of university science departments with SFES faculty members has begun to emerge as a response to critical challenges in three key arenas in U.S. science education: 1) discipline-based science education research, 2) undergraduate science education, and 3) K-12 science education. This project is examining academic climates and institutional contexts for SFES positions addressing the research question "In what institutional contexts have SFES positions emerged, what has motivated this, and what is the perceived impact of SFES?" The study is examining explicitly the various perspectives in different science disciplines and at different institution types; primarily undergraduate, MS-granting, and PhD-granting institutions. In addressing the main research question, the study is focusing on three underlying questions:
- What are the initial reasons for creating SFES positions?
- How do departmental stakeholders (including the SFES faculty themselves) conceptualize the purposes of SFES positions?
- What is the impact and institutional influence of SFES?

The intellectual merit of this project lies in the need to understand the roles and impacts of SFES faculty, particularly their contribution to a reform agenda. Data are largely absent. The cross-disciplinary research team is qualified to examine SFES nationally because of its work defining the SFES field. It has recently completed a national survey to determine who are in the national SFES faculty based on a combination of factors, including self-identification. The national survey data and this exploratory study of the SFES academic climates in different departments and institutional contexts are possible indicators of readiness to engage in evidence based teaching reforms at the departmental level.

The broader impact of this study is its potential value to funders and policymakers seeking to improve undergraduate STEM education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Science education is fundamental to the preparedness of our citizens to participate in an increasingly technological world and our national success in the global economy. However, students in science classes regularly encounter difficulties that greatly reduce their ability to learn science and appreciate the importance of science in our society. One approach for accelerating improvements in science education is to incorporate faculty level scientists with an expertise in science education directly into science departments in colleges and universities. This type of faculty person, which we identify as Science Faculty with Education Specialties (SFES), takes on specialized roles in science education within college and university science departments to strengthen undergraduate science education, improve K-12 science education, and conduct discipline-based education research. The hiring of SFES is a widespread and growing approach in the United States to improving science education in all these areas, however, data about SFES and the impacts are largely absent. There have been few formal investigations of this approach, which appears to be an emergent phenomenon originating from within scientific disciplines, rather than a strategy being specifically funded or externally directed. Thus, SFES positions are widespread and growing, yet also understudied and apparently undirected.

 

The intellectual merit of this project is that our cross-disciplinary research team provides quantitative and qualitative findings that can inform institutional and policy discussions about science faculty engaging with science education, as well as decisions regarding the conceptualization of the structure and support for such positions in order to maximize the conditions for promoting the institutional and national impact of current and future SFES in advancing science education. Specifically, we conducted 50 interviews of SFES at PhD-granting, MS-granting, and primarily undergraduate institutions using a stratified, random sampling design and produced over 3000 minutes of transcribed interview data. The data analysis and grounded theory coding addressed several research questions with a deeper analysis of the types of science education impacts at departmental, institutional, and extra-institutional levels by the study participants. We coded and quantified overall SFES professional impacts across the arenas of science education, by sub-categories within the arenas, and by institution type. Our analyses indicated that SFES are actively supporting all areas of science education with 80% reporting professional impacts in undergraduate science education and 62% of SFES are influencing the teaching practices of their departmental colleagues. Because typical college and university science faculty are frequently hired with little to no training in effective science teaching, SFES in science departments and their ability to influence the practices of department faculty can significantly impact and strengthen undergraduate science education within science departments. We produced three research manuscripts for publication as peer-reviewed journal articles:

1)  “Widespread distribution and unexpected variation among science faculty with education specialties (SFES) across the United States,” Bush et al., Proc Natl Acad Sci USA, 2013, 110(18):7170-5.

2) “Misalignments: Challenges in Cultivating Science Faculty with Education Specialties in Your Department,” Bush et al., Bioscience, 2015, 65(1):81-89.

3) “Fostering Change from Within: Influencing Teaching Practices of Departmental Colleagues by Science Faculty with Education Specialties,” Bush et al., PLOS ONE, revised submission under review
